column4: P.U. -- but good for non-discriminating 7 year olds.
column5: This "film" and I use that term loosely reminds me of the first joke my daughter wrote at eighteen months: "P.U. stinky poopies!"Like that joke this movie can only appeal to the very young the very immature or the very stupid.That said there are a few bright spots.The effects where the majority of the reputed $100 million went are kinetic and convincing -- I mean as convincing as those kind of kinetic CGI effects can be. The CGI baby effects are not great but I imagine those are very hard to do well... although for a hundred-million bucks they could have been better!Moose the dog from "Frasier" phoned in his usual exemplary performance. Steven Wright did well with a small part. Alan Cummings was well Alan Cummings-as-villain which we've seen before and Bob Hoskins as Odin was unrecognizable but enjoyable.The actress playing Mrs. Avery was cute-as-a-button as you'd expect and Jamie Kennedy stunk as you'd expect. His best role so far was in the Scream trilogy (not to be confused with the Lord of the Rings trilogy) and in Three Kings. He should stick perhaps to more subtle forms of comedy. Jim Carrey he ain't.The writing and direction were if anything worse than Kennedy's performance. I semi-remember one clever (though seven-year-old clever) line that I wish someone would quote accurately for the "Memorable Quotes" section. Something about Avery's proposed costume being the "crappiest crap in Craptown" it was a second-grade joke but sort of funny in context.Over all since there's nothing lower than a "one" I give this film a "one."

column4: Breathtakingly bad.
column5: In a year that has already given us the eye-searingly appalling 'Alone In The Dark' and following a previous summer of such spectacular errors of judgement as 'Catwoman' 'Baby Geniuses 2' and Disney's 'Around The World In Eighty Days' it was hard to imagine how much more self-flagellation Hollywood could suffer without at least stopping to notice the blood. But at least Uwe Boll works for peanuts; some $84 million has been thrown away in this worst-of-the-worst retelling of a joke that stopping breathing some eight years ago after Jim Carrey and the Saturday morning cartoon show had flogged it to death. Skid row just got a bigger development grant too; now Alan Cummings and Bob Hoskins have both swan-dived into the cinematic dumpster for Christian 'Carnby' Slater to point his finger at and laugh.So much has been written already by so many verbose movie buffs about what a conceptual artistic aesthetic (and no doubt financial) catastrophe this exercise in utter pointlessness is. column4: A Disturbing display of unfunny jokes hideous aesthetic quality and shocking overall delivery.
column5: I know a lot of people don't like sequels. Some say they endanger the first film by maybe disgracing it others say they're just a cash in. Sometimes filmmakers get it right (Terminator 2: Judgement Day) but other times they get it wrong. Son of the Mask is a great example of an instance when they do just that. Son of the Mask has to be one of the worst sequels of all time and even though the first Mask film was no classic it had its moments and I truly mean that. What Son of the Mask is is nothing more than a nasty to look at nasty to watch mess of bad and unfunny jokes mixed in with horrible music and nasty to look at visuals.From the off Son of the Mask begins its terrible decent into celluloid waste. It messes around very dangerously with the original Mask film's premise. We are told that Loki: the Nordic God of mischief created the mask in question and banished it himself to Earth for people to find fool around with and create mischief of their own. It's Loki's job in this film to find it by rule of Odin so that he can get back into Valhalla or wherever. This immediately goes against the first film as we were told Loki was in fact BANISHED from his heaven and imprisoned inside this mask that was then placed on the earth; hopefully for no one to ever find. Thus destroying the equilibrium. This is the first mistake the film makes of many and if you can't even get your equilibriums right you're in big trouble.First of all; the characters. Loki in this film is evil. He is genuinely evil and it spoils the image that was created in the first film when he was a mischievous funny maybe misunderstood God. In Son of the Mask he acts as the villain of the piece and that is very disorientating especially if you've seen the first film and I had a big problem with this. Then we move onto the supposed hero. The hero is Tim Avery (Kennedy) a comic book artist who lacks big inspiration. The fact he has one of the most annoying voices I've ever heard in a film and acts like a twelve year old throughout is enough to utterly repel you from any sort of feeling or relation towards him. These are bad principals for a hero to have. Thirdly when we actually see our hero wear the mask; its not only a let down as so much as a shockingly unfunny and downright embarrassing series of events that I've ever witnessed in a film.The scene in question is the company he works for and their large function they're having. There's no build up like their was in the first film there's no motivation to even wear the mask and our hero's position in Son of the Mask isn't as desperate as Ipkiss' was in the first film. Anyway once the mask goes on; we're treated to an absolutely hideous display of camera work including close ups of the ugly Mask character's face fast editing as we struggle to grasp what it is we're seeing music so bad you have to cover your ears and dance numbers so cringe-worthingly bad that it hurts to watch.Then comes the plot. The plot is straight forward enough as I've explained. Loki's trying to find his mask that he supposedly created. What happens is Loki spends so much time going from house to house trying to find his Mask that I personally began to stop caring. Each visit was just an excuse to 'do something funny' and with jokes so blatantly aimed at children; it was difficult to watch. Another thing is the pointless 'in there for laughs' subplot that opens up. This involves the baby that's born that is given the powers of the mask. Halfway through the child seems it fit to copy various cartoons on the TV to try and get their father (who's the hero) condemned to a mental institute. This is bad enough as the writers aren't even using their own initiative to create material. To counteract this the family's dog attempts to defy the baby. Although maybe funny the first time this quickly plays out into utter farce and serves no bearing on the rest of the film; it's just a pointless mess of jokes and gags that makes you feel like you're watching an episode of Road Runner vs. Wile E. Coyote. During this for some reason the father doesn't actually think of perhaps filming the baby or something like that rather than pick him up and run to the neighbour's house; thus trying to convince them the baby can sing and dance. Oh look it's stopped: what a surprise.Plot holes? You bet. Loki has his powers taken away from him and is made mortal during a scrap in an alley way; yet survives the baby's counterattack of having two rubbish skips crush him. He's literally just been made mortal yet survives being crushed. Another instance is nearer the end when Avery's Mask character does battle with Loki over the child. Loki states 'Stop! We are evenly matched!' Well of course you are! The guy's wearing your mask; he has your powers. It took them about ten minutes to figure that out(!) I also really feel that although the acting talent it has on display if they'd have known it was going to be anything like how it was they would've kept well away. With these things and a few hundred plot holes heaped on top Son of the Mask can easily be labelled as one of the worst films ever made; in fact it makes 'The Mask' look like a masterpiece.

column4: Not a Jim Carrey classic but hilarious nonetheless
column5: I just finished this movie and my cheeks hurt from the grinning. Son of the Mask expands on the story of Jim Carrey classic The Mask in a whole different way. A baby is conceived while the father is wearing the titular mask and 9 months later unto the world is born a nightmare child with cartoon god-like powers. On top of this the pet dog now jealous of the baby getting all the attention has gotten its paws on the mask and become a green-faced revenge-seeking cartoon mutt.Meanwhile Loki the fabled God of mischief (mentioned in the original movie not featured) has been instructed by his father Odin to retrieve his mask due to the havoc it caused in the first film. Loki is the essence of the Mask and thus can also turn green and do the Jim Carrey routine coming to a total of four equally bizarre Mask-like characters though obviously none living up to Jim Carrey.The father and hero of the movie is played by Jamie Kennedy the funny chap who was the film buff in the Scream movies ("Did you put her liver in the mailbox? Because I read that the killer put her liver in the mailbox...") and he does a good job. Upon donning the mask he becomes the plastic-haired catsuit-clad cheesy game show host type (nice to see more different takes on what the mask does to different people) who is amusing though feels a little unnatural compared to the his acting in "Dad form".Plenty of great CG just like the original some spectacular visuals and designs and for a movie so different to it's predecessor and so much more family friendly it certainly does a good job of recreating the original atmosphere with nice lighting and settings.So would I recommend it? If you're a hardcore fan of The Mask in the form of comic book movie or even cartoon probably not because it's not what you will want from a sequel. For slightly more open-minded people looking for some fun and a few smiles of nostalgia from nods to the original totally. It's a side-splitter particularly for kids.There's no obligation to have seen the original; it works as a film on it's own as well as a sequel so don't worry if you want to entertain your very young kids but don't want to expose them to some of the more "PG" humour of the original. Then perhaps they can check the original out when they're a few years older.Underrated and great fun. It may not be the "Revenge of the Mask" movie we were promised all those years ago and it's not a masterpiece by any means (what sequel is?) but it's really nice to see a clever and creative sequel/followup to a film whose chances as a franchise we all thought were dead.

column5: I didn't know what I wasn't getting myself into: usually I am not too fond of sequels. And this one didn't disappoint me either. Actually that's exactly what I am saying: no Jim = no hilarity no falling off your chair funny no uniqueness. Writing could have been better (a lot of information is given for granted so you have to fill in using your own brain) but overall the plot holds together. column4: The Pointless Sequel To The Mask: A Review Of Son Of The Mask
column5: It is common especially for Hollywood to churn out a sequel that is not as good as its original blockbuster. Watch the very weak Men in Black 2 to understand this completely in contrast to its witty sci-fi comedy of an original. However after viewing such a flawed fantasy I recommend this is how low you can go to make a horrible sequel! Choppy editing. The camera work was poor! You name a flaw in film-making and realise how many you can find in this doomed project. This is a visual guide how not to make film unless of course you are a studio executive who couldn't care less that such a film is bad but a money-making venture for its franchise. As you cannot tell I think this is how such a poor sequel was introduced.So what did I hate about this film? Was it the fact that they tried to be more creative than its predecessor? Yes by the bowl full! In the original they at least had someone who gave an "animated performance" to the main character who pulls all sorts of codes and convention from the world of Hollywood animation. I am talking of no one but some Canadian comedian known as Jim Carrey in a role I thought was suitable for his brand of goofy talents. However viewing the Son of the Mask they fail to impress me with such antics that I could not stand any more and cringed for every time such an antic was performed.Was another reason the fact got anything to do with the plot of a struggling animator wanting his idea to become a show? Through that perspective I guess not. But this sub-plot failed to make such a focus on the narrative of this film instead they went to re-invent the antics that made The Mask entertaining that I couldn't even care less about this animation-orientated sub-plot. Also the fact is the film focuses on Poki trying to get that Mask back to his father was the main narrative. column4: All sizzle nooooo steak.
column5: Having nearly no continuity or connection to the first film Jamie Kennedy plays Tim Avery an under-appreciated loser who desperately wants to make it as an animator. So when an unexpected bundle of joy comes along he gets more than he bargained for... oh god. Cheesy premise yes but is it watchable? There are only two reasons this movie was made. One: Money. (duh.) Two: an exercise in animation techniques and physical effects. Like those straight-to-tape Disney sequels this movie strikes me as "practise" for animators and animation techniques. That said the different animations and computer graphics throughout the movie are very good and are amalgamated with the live action fairly well. However besides that and the surprising heartfelt 'message' near the end of the movie the good stuff pretty much ends there.Jim Carrey MADE the original movie. Now Jamie Kennedy has shown his versatility behind a disguise on 'The Jamie Kennedy Experiment' yet he seemed really restricted and NON-wild in his subpar prosthetics. Sadly even a decent performance from super talented Alan Cumming couldn't really help a script that really seems to go all over the place. Add to all this a CG animated baby that "doesn't quite look right" and you have yet another shallow attempt to cash in on a surprisingly profitable original.Is "Son Of The Mask" worth watching for the average viewer? I don't think so. Is this harmless family viewing? Mostly. But if you're an animation buff like I am and grew up on those Tex Avery-type cartoons you MIGHT be able to appreciate this movie for that aspect. 2 out of 10.

column4: It was bad but it wasn't THAT bad...
column5: It's a bit outrageous seeing this film in the bottom 100. I can think of heaps of other films that are worse than this. Sure this film is in bad taste and it doesn't have Jim Carrey but it really wasn't that bad. It was bad sure and I think a couple of the jokes were a bit too crude for my taste but people are really overreacting. The movie is just meant to be a silly crude comedy to watch when your bored. It's definitely not deserving of a 2.2/10.Let me get this clear: Jim Carrey was my favourite thing in the original The Mask. He was very funny and I loved the movie because of his comedic skills. This film of course isn't as great because Jim Carrey is in it and because the jokes are a bit too crude for people's taste so I can semi-understand if this got mixed reviews but the reviews are horrendous...Christ.We'll start off with the pros first.Some of the humour in this was quite good. I liked the fast-motion jokes they used in this which they used in the original. You know when he puts on the mask and he goes fast? Yeah the filmmakers of this understood the humour of this joke and they used it in their original unique way. I enjoyed the slapstick humour in this which I won't give away and I especially enjoyed Otis who was a constant gag throughout the film that was very funny. The pacing in this is way too fast unfortunately but I suppose it just matches with the humour in this film.It knows it's audience and it knows what it's doing. The film knows that it's a crude tasteless comedy which is why I think this film's underrated. It knows how to pull off a gag at the right time and none of the jokes ever seem to be forced when you watch this. So there's another pro.Now for the cons.I absolutely hated the CGI in this. It was horrendous cringe worthy and annoying. I can see where the hate for the CGI comes from it was horrible I felt repulsed watching the CGI.The gags involving potty humour weren't funny. I know how I said that it was just meant to be a crude tasteless comedy but I think this went a bit too far with the potty humour. It was way too crude for my taste and I can clearly agree that the potty humour was too much and it made me lose my appetite a bit. I had to pause the film for a few minutes so I could vomit.The original The Mask felt to be the better experience. When I watched this I enjoyed some moments and laughed but in The Mask I think it felt more coherent and normal rather than jumpy and energetic like this one. The original The Mask also had Jim Carrey which I think really boosted the original from this one. If your going to watch this expecting it to be as good as the original don't watch it.Overall I think it was a bad film but it was nowhere as bad as critics are saying. You may like it if you can stomach crude humour but if you can't I don't think you will. 4.8/10.

column4: Making this movie was a sin
column5: Loki Norse god of mischief creates a mask that endows the wearer with cartoon-like powers. At the command of his father Odin he spends the rest of the movie looking for the mask so that it can cause no further grief to mankind. In the meantime the possessor of the mask conceives a child who inherits the powers of the mask. Etc. etc. If this sounds like a pretty thin plot line it is. Add to this the fact that the movie is handled ineptly from start to finish and the result is very very bad. You can find worse movies but you'll have to actively search for them.For the most part Son of the Mask is presented at the intellectual level of a pre-schooler but in light of scenes such as the mask-baby urinating copiously in six different directions including on his father this premise seems unlikely. I asked my son who he thought might have been the target audience for the movie and he responded "Convicted felons" apparently forgetting for the moment that the Constitution prohibits cruel and unusual punishment.But just making a bad movie is not a sin or Hell would be overflowing. What makes it a sin is that $72 million was spent on this piece of garbage. To put things in perspective the day after we watched Son of the Mask my son and I watched "Good Night and Good Luck" a movie that garnered six academy award nominations (including best picture) and was brought in for $7 million. That's right. Just one-tenth of the amount of money spent on Son of the Mask. This then is the sin -- to flush good money down the sewer when it could have been better used in making watchable movies or feeding starving children or for that matter almost any other purpose. The producers should truly be ashamed of themselves.

column4: Could have been SO much better.. and still can

The cutting director gets a 3This movie is no more than storyboard outline strung together haphazardly.The scenario/plot is good but it's too convoluted and suggestive of writing by committee where no one took charge and said: "Look THIS is the track we're taking" and enforced it.As for the poor acting I think you can blame it on that as well. column4: Slightly better than Garfield..
column5: Normally when judging movies it is useful to consider the context of what it is trying to be. Now unless "Son of the Mask" was TRYING to be a saccharine CG-fetishizing suck fest it probably missed its mark.Jamie Kennedy is truly an underrated creative talent whom I hoped would carry the movie. Add in Ben Stein Bob Hoskins Kal Penn and a refreshing supporting role by Steven Wright and you can see how much screen time was wasted on drawn-out cartoonish action sequences and digital manipulations of the baby's three expressions.Taking into account the director's previous work on "Cats and Dogs" and "Antz" it is easy to see the source of the neglect: human characters (and actors) seem to take a back seat to novelty leads under Guterman's direction.Several segments were entirely over-descriptive of the plot/upcoming action to even be considered subtle foreshadowing including a gratuitous 2-minute synopsis of a classic cartoon. Rather than innovative media sampling and dynamic background asides certain parts just come off as cinematic laziness.There's nothing wrong with a little toilet humor especially in a kid's movie; however some of the bodily fluid scenes would probably be considered profane by the FCC.The special effects were pretty seamless and elaborated on the conventions established by the first film but for the most part served as lengthy breaks from plot advancement and character development. They certainly got the right FX house because ILM has plenty of experience in this field! Alan Cummings played a dynamic and likable villain and Traylor Howard a generic but hot Gen-Xer mom.Overall the movie had its moments but missed the boat by ignoring a talented and capable cast and dumbing down the humor to the point of being patronizing even to children. The best kids movies work on several levels.I'd recommend sitting this one out and giving the rug rats something to do for 86 minutes.

column4: If something isn't broken don't try and fix it !!
column5: OMG !!!!!!!. I am embarrassed to say that I have just sat through the entire movie. I suppose you can't give a proper review if you don't. It is very easily the worst film I have ever seen.I watched the premier of the original Mask in '93 and was completely blown away. I went back a couple of days later to see it again because I enjoyed it so much.A classic is best left alone without a sequel. For me it was not even worthy of calling a sequel. The screenplay was crap the acting was crap the so-called special effects were a ridiculous attempt to recreate some of the funnier scenes of the original but completely failed on all levels.Ed Wood was probably the worst director of all time and his film " Plan 9 from Outer Space " is reputed to be the worst film of all time. I love it!! It really IS so crap that it is funny because of that fact. Son of the Mask on the other hand is like taking a classic such as The Green Mile or Shawshank Redemption and making a 3rd rate cartoon out of them voiced by actors with completely no substance.A franchise CAN consist of only one film and this is a perfect example.How Bob Hoskins and one of my favourite comedians Steven Wright got mixed up in this pile of trash is one of the great mysteries of the universe.AVOID AT ALL COSTS !!!

column4: A tolerable movie plagued by it's divergence from the original.
column5: I believe that the biggest problem facing this movie is that it seems to have attempted in every way to divorce itself from it's predecessor.Intentional or not the target audience has obviously shifted. My children are young enough that I would not consider allowing them to watch "The mask" nor would I expect them to enjoy it. This incarnation however has been toned down significantly and I have few qualms about allowing them to watch this film other than the few instances of potty humor. My kids loved this. It was madcap and cartoonish.I on the other hand would not watch it again. For the adult audience the sets are garish the acting is amateurish the plot is a cute idea but never fully fleshed out the mythological references are shallow the character development is weak and inconsistent and the characters are difficult to care about.To give an idea of this film if you were to blend "Who Framed Roger Rabbit" and the "It's a good life" segment of "Twilight Zone: the movie" and throw in a pinch of writing styles from any of the nickelodeon sitcom line-up you'd get a reasonable notion of this film.This is one to let your young kids watch if you don't mind that it has absolutely no beneficial qualities other than it's pre-juvenile entertainment value and does resort to the occasional booger-level slapstick. If you want your kids to get something useful educational or spiritually strengthening out of their medium look somewhere else.Quite simply put if you're old enough to remember "The Mask" fondly and want more of that which it had to offer... THIS IS NOT IT. This is a movie with NO ENTERTAINMENT VALUE for ANYONE but young children and parents who enjoy watching shallow mindless children's' movies with their kids like me. It does not offer the depth of ANYTHING that could be considered classic and I anticipate that it be forgotten very quickly.Overall It's not a BAD BAD movie... It's just not a GOOD movie. My kid's had a good time.***Spoiler*** Steven Wright is in this film and doesn't have even one single funny thing to say. This is just wrong.

column4: Two elements make this movie bad: the script and Jamie Kennedy's attempt at doing the Mask character.
column5: The script: The script is pretty bad. Dog finds mask...Jamie wears mask to party...Jamie comes back home and knocks up wife...they have a baby. Thus the son of the mask. Baby has ridiculous cartoon-ish powers while the god LOKI is trying to get the mask back as it was a god creation. So dumb. And if you think Jamie Kennedy doing the Mask was bad look no further than Bob Hoskins character Odin. Every time he enters he is yelling...what is up with that? The whole Odin/Loki gods stuff is such a stupid angle.Jamie Kennedy and the mask: What made the original Mask movie great was Jim Carrey. Not only did Carrey act the Mask better his "Mask" was dressed much more appropriate. The Mask character was modeled after the Wolf character in Tex Avery's cartoons. Jim Carrey portrayed that character almost perfect with the clothing the voice the actions...everything. Mind I note Jim Carrey's face is much thinner and therefore works better in mimicking the wolf character. Jamie Kennedy has a fat face is dressed in horrible clothing wears this UGLY red wig and worst of all his voice over on the mask is horrible...not to mention his acting as "Tim Avery". The Mask here is more like...a cartoon version of Mo Collins (from MadTV) doing that character who never finishes her sentences and continues to go higher and higher with her voice. It is horrible. There is little if any evidence of the Son of the Mask resembling Tex Avery's creations. Jamie Kennedy's performance alone makes this movie very hard to watch.

column4: One of the worst films I have ever EVER had the misfortune of seeing.
column5: The original "Mask" movie made me appreciate Jim Carrey's comedic talents (though I still say he should do some more serious roles- "The Truman Show" blew me away). It had a wild anarchic almost over the top style that meant it left an impact- and Carrey was perfect for the film.Now along comes this stinker.Let me start by saying this- if you value your life keep the hell away from this movie. I only just survived and even then I had to saw off one of my arms. Want more proof as to how stupefyingly horrible this dreck is? It's on the IMDb Bottom 100 and quite honestly one of the worst films I have ever seen.Plan 9 From Outer Space is widely regarded to be the worst film of all time- and one of the funniest. Why? Because that's how bad it it. The aliens are guys in gorilla suits with fish bowls one their heads. The graves used in the graveyard seen are cardboard and wobble whenever the wind blows. The aliens use human desks and pens. And the U.F.O.s are hubcaps being dangled around on visible strings. Why do I mention this? It's very simple: in ten years time Son of the Mask will be considered the Plan 9 of our generation. The already bad effects will look terrible.The only likable character is surprisingly Loki. I didn't mind the actor playing him but the rest got on my nerves. Who the heck is Jamie Kennedy anyway/And who wrote this film? A five year old?I still have nightmares from this form of child abuse projected onto the big screen. Someone forced me to watch it. I later shot them.The scariest thing is there were tons of people involved in making this ****fest.Avoid.

column4: Computer Graphics Do Not Maketh A Movie
column5: Oh dear! I had so looked forward to a Mask sequel. Ever since showing the trailer and eagerly putting the original through the projector I knew that there had to be a follow-up. OK so it wasn't Jim Carey but I thought it might be watchable. What follows is visual gag on top of visual gag and to be honest they just aren't funny. Why? Quite simply there is no timing. Imagine a stand up comedian reeling off jokes without taking a breath and you will soon find it boring. It would help if there was a plot or a little tension thrown in but I think more emphasis was given to set design. And to think of all the hours spent on the visuals. It really is a crying shame but I am being convinced more everyday that the art of film-making is being replaced by bright colours that bounce around the screen. My sympathies go out to highly talented Alan Cumming for being coerced into this. No doubt he was promised that it was going to be big big big. Take my advice and watch the original again (that goes to the production team too).

column4: They messed with a success.
column5: Want it or not The Mask starring Jim Carrey was an amazing success. The story was not perfect but we can't forget it was a comedy and the kind of film din't require anything extremely good. But it was a success. Jim Carrey an excellent comedian and revealed to be a great dancer too. The effects the characters the environment everything was pretty good and made it a very good movie. Almost everybody associates Jim Carrey to the Mask ans vise-versa.Son of the mask is a disaster... and awful disaster. Everybody knows that making a second movie after a great success is risky and almost every time is not so good as the first one. In this case the "not so good" could be a compliment as Son Of The Mask revealed to be the worst movie i ever seen. But why? So here it goes: 1º - The characters are bad. they're personality is horrible complete loosers (not like Stanley Hipkiss not even close.). 2º - The actors are the worst i have ever seen. Come on people... making a second mask movie without Jim Carrey ??? or without any actor with the same status as Jim?? I mean professionals! These guys can'0t even act as ordinary people in they's day-to-day lives... When I saw this Jamie Kennedy as the mask.... Jesus.... i couldn't believe... it was SO INCREDIBLY BAD!!! The make up the posture the face everything.... the guy doesn't even move any muscle in his face... I can't believe they destroyed The Mask this way... people put this in your mind: there will never be any Mask like Jim Carrey. Or even close! 3º The story is incredibly bad... when people watch a movie there is supposed to be a connection between the watcher and the movie. there has got to be something interesting something funny something that makes you see the movie until the end. And actually like the movie. You don't have any connection to this movie. You star to watch and you wonder when it is over 'cause it's so bad you want to stop watching it! 4º Don't have the skill don't mess. This title completely destroyed the mask the funny the mask was. After a decade people still watch the original The Mask starring Jim Carrey and they still laugh an enjoy the movie as if it was the first time it was seen. With this disgusting sequel i'm afraid The Mask looses it's beauty in comedy and it's magic.So my advice is: if you liked very much The Mask don't you dare to watch this Son Of The Mask thing 'cause you're gonna get disappointed and very sad about what they've done with the original title. If you loved The Mask forget that Son Of The Mask has ever been made. But actually my advice is: EVERYONE -> DON'T WATCH THIS DON'T RENT IT DON'T BUY IT. IT'S SSSSSOOOOOOOOOO BBBBAAAAAADDDDDD!!!!!I even saw someone's review saying that this Son Of The Mask is a great movie for kids... please... children are not "stupid beings". Can't they have good content on what they see anymore ? But that also has another point... The Mask was not supposed to be ONLY for kids... The original Mask was a movie for everyone!! AND IT WAS GOOD. I'm not just complaining i mean Son Of The Mask is an interesting title i actually lead me to watch it. but please.... why use these title in such an awful movie?? why not a GOOD sequel???I'm sorry Lawrence Guterman but you could have done MUCH better. I know it's a cheap movie to direct... but the result is the worst thing i've ever seen and i'm not the only one.And by the way to all actors of this movie specially to Jamie Kennedy: go to acting school or go there again. learn something there and come back to the movie business. And learn as well what is true comedy. Learn with Jim.And if any director is thinking about making another movie about The Mask... please.... choose experts choose great actors great comedians great effects great music and great story. otherwise... don't mess anymore don't destroy The Mask anymore.

column4: This movie flat out sucks.
column5: I used to love cartoons and better yet I still do but I'm surprised to how modern day technology can give cartoons the look but fail so horribly on giving it the heart or for that matter the screen time. If there was ever a movie where million dollar CGI were wasted on purpose due to a wretched plot outline this would be that movie. I'm sure there will be others but for now we're stuck with this.SON OF THE MASK is another Jim Carrey pre-sequel (DUMB AND DUMBERER in 2003) but to my knowledge at least that movie had a Jim Carrey lookalike. How Jamie Kennedy got this role is a hardcore mystery and a mystery like this is best left alone to keep his websites full of happy fans. This film is a dreadful putrid obsolete cinematic failure with a story that's as entertaining as watching a multi-colored ice cube melt in the hand of a burn victim. The Bottom line? Jamie Kennedy plays Tim an animator that discovers the mask from his dog Otis. He wears it and while under the so called 'curse' of the mask he impregnates his wife. So we get a baby with special super human powers. Later on and I'm just guessing the numbers we sit through a $1'000'000 CGI trick of Otis transforming into a cartoon dog after putting on the mask. Otis has a grudge against the baby due to the fact that Tim and his wife enjoy his presence more. So we sit through a similar 1950's cartoon scheme of Otis and the baby blowing each other up using both good old fashion explosive and inflation techniques. This I'm also guessing is $500'000. But by this point of the movie you've probably already left the theater and I cant say I blame you.I'm not against crude animation on principle and this is just me I've always wanted to be a cartoon Dragon that becomes inflated to the size of a planet as a means of making someone smile giggle or even become aroused out of my frustration and size but when cartoon characters are made miserable on purpose because of a poorly written script it makes me think of how many dollars I saved by watching this movie online.It's offensively bad to the eyes and ears of classic American cartoon craver's. Consider a scene near the end of the movie that involves a rip-off of THE EXORCIST where the baby vomits gallons of green goo onto the dashboard as a means of freaking out his dad. By this point of the film I'm betting that you're at home on the RAZZIE@ website voting for worst picture.
